Varengold Bank AG is a German private bank with its headquarter in Hamburg and maintains locations in Dubai and London. Varengold offers its customers and business partners a variety of products and services within the business areas Capital Markets, Commercial Banking and Capital Markets Brokerage.

Varengold was founded as an asset management boutique in the year 1995 seeking to offer individual and high-performing financial products. Following its great success in Asset Management, the bank extended its business in 1998 to include Capital Markets Brokerage. Customers receive access to the world-renowned trading platform MetaTrader and are able to trade in forex, CFDs and commodities on a single account. With the receipt of the commercial banking license in 2013 the business area Commercial Banking was established and affects further synergies with the already existing business areas.

Varengold Bank AG is registered with the German Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin) under number 109 520/100 and has been listed on the Entry Standard of Deutsche Börse in Frankfurt since the 20th of March 2007 (ISIN DE0005479307, WKN 547930). Varengold Bank AG is also connected to the Compensatory Fund of German Banks (EdB).

Should note that Deutsche's turned positive on Glencore though. First broker to do so in a while.

11:21 am
BE

Rene Kleyweg De Monchy is the analyst.

BE

Yes, really.

BE

In addition to the normal production update, Glencore has provided details of
its near-term financial position in an effort to address market concerns.
Liquidity has increased by $3.3bn since June. The targeted $2.7bn reduction in
RMI based on FY guidance is significantly ahead of the $1.5bn reduction in
working capital outlined prior to the equity raising. And the $25bn net debt
target by year end is well on the way to the low $20b’s targeted for YE16. 2015
Marketing EBIT guidance of US$2.5-2.6b maintained. With the stock
overcoming debt fears, ongoing catalysts this year and trading below our PT,
we upgrade to Buy.

11:21 am
BE

75% of the US$10b debt reduction plan is locked in. As a scorecard check: 1)
US$2.5b equity issue (done). 2) US$2.4b from full year and interim dividend
cut (Board announced). 3) US$1.5b in working cap reduction (Exceeded). End
September committed liquidity increase to US$13.8b indicates that US$1.6 has
been released already with a US$2.7b year-end target). 4) US$2b asset sales
(US$0.9b silver stream announced overnight with another to follow this year –
combined with Agri sales, this is likely to beat). 5)US$0.5-0.8b reduction in
advances (no update as yet), 6) US$0.5-1b capex reduction (no update).

BE

2015 production guidance was adjusted for the previously announced copper
and zinc cuts. Total copper cuts were increased from 400kt over 18 months to
455kt by YE2017. It announced a forward sale of 140Moz of its Antamina silver
by-product at 20% of the spot price for an up-front payment of US$900m. Post
the 140Moz its forward sales drop to 2/3 of its share. On our forecasts (LT Ag
US$20/oz), this drops our NPV by US$1,049m, so the US$900 payment is
mildly NPV dilutive (but will impact positively on liquidity and share price).

BE

Our R47 price target is based on our DCF-derived NPV (WACC 8.6%, CoD 4%,
Gearing 20%, Tax 20%, RfR 3.0%). Downside risks include lower commodity
prices than expected (particularly copper and zinc) or stronger operating
currency (particularly the AUD). Glencore still needs to rebuild its relationship
and trust with equity investors. However the rapid debt reduction plans should
remove the balance sheet and trading fears that have overly impacted the
share price. Through to 1Q16 we should see a number of positive catalysts
including additional asset sales.

PM

11:23 am
BE

Financing and liquidity in focus: Debunking misinformation
With credit & liquidity a key focus for GLEN of late, we address a few issues where we
believe there could be misunderstanding in the market:
There are covenants on Glencore’s debt instruments, bonds, RCFS, etc. Not true.
Glen has $15 bn in debt maturities next year. No. the $9 bn RCF that appears as
“due” on Bloomberg can be rolled for a year, without condition, for minimal cost (25
bps). As such, 2016 maturities are c. US$5 bn vs. c. $13 bn of liquidity post recent raise.
Letters of credit (LCs) are another form of debt. Not really. LCs from banks “back”
payables (essentially a bank guarantee to suppliers) and make global trade work.
Glencore has c. $50 bn in “rolling” LCs available. Around $17.8 bn of LC was “at the half
year (against $28 bn of payables). Glencore’s letters of credit are provided by around 70
banks. According to the company, no letters of credit were pulled in 2009. LCs are
relatively cheap (c. 50 bps annually) and are Basel III friendly for banks. LCs are a
standard product used across the commodity trading industry.
CDS widening could cause customers to avoid trading business. Possible but we
think unlikely. Inasmuch as LCs back payables, a supplier’s direct risk is with a bank, not
GLEN directly.

BE

Asset sales won’t happen because there are no buyers. We don’t think this is true.
Gold streams are a fairly standard product (we’ve said before that this could raise up to
US$1.7 bn). Agricultural assets trade at high multiples and, in our view, for the right
assets (such as the former Viterra assets) we think that a deal can get done .
Back to the US$50 bn question…
For much of this year, we have been asking the $50 bn question (“How much new equity
do the miners need”). Key thesis: Flattening cost curves = lower commodity prices =
balance sheets & dividends under pressure. Our Sept 1st revision of this note included a
“Doom & Gloom” scenario which suggested that Glencore’s equity could have limited
equity in certain situations. We stand by this analysis. With lower growth in China,
flattening cost curves & lowered expectations for long term commodity prices,
companies with high operational and financial leverage will come under pressure.
Acknowledging a problem the first step to fixing it
That said, we do believe that GLEN’s management has acknowledged the problem by
suspending the dividend, raising equity and announcing asset disposals. This is a move
beyond the denial that we see in other companies, hence our recent upgrade to Neutral.
We have written on GLEN’s plan raise money via streaming deals, via a sell-down in its
Agricultural business (press reports $12 bn implied EV! A bit high perhaps.) and, in a last
resort, via a sell-down of Tier 1 copper assets. We maintain our Neutral rating. We are
cautious copper, a key product for Glencore forecasting c. $4500/t for 2016, 2017.

BE

Still only neutral though.

11:26 am
BE

Fresh cuts to our estimates: -7% to our FY15e EBIT and -15% to FY16e
Our cuts essentially reflect a sharper deterioration in diamonds, leading us to drastically cut our expected EBIT contribution from De Beers (30% of AAL EBIT). While we leave other commodity price forecasts unchanged, we are 12% below cons. on FY15e EPS and 14% below FY16e. Diamonds outlook worsening beyond our fears – still very low visibility on a bottom
The downturn seen on the diamond market has gone beyond our fears. Excess polished
inventories, financing profitability issues in the mid-stream, and a slowdown in demand have further worsened conditions after an already weak H1. De Beers sales volumes in Q3 were down
59% yoy. Visibility on a possible bottom in the short term (Q2 16e?) remains low. Beyond that, the risk is that the build-up of an inventory overhang in rough diamonds, currently in the making, will cap any potential price recovery once end markets stabilise.
Balance sheet disposals remain in focus. Dividend cut almost certain but more is needed
While we see no funding or covenant risk short term, the level of leverage remains clearly
uncomfortable with ND/EBITDA greater than 4x in FY16e at spot commodities prices. It looks now highly
probable that the company will announce a cut in its dividend (with potentially a new policy) before
year end. In addition, delivering on asset sales remains crucial. Ex-Tarmac proceeds are set to be
very limited (c. USD300m this year). More is needed and it now looks likely that assets which were not initially expected to be sold will be considered. Recent rumours on Niobium / Phosphate look credible to us (possibly USD1bn). Samancor could be also considered, in our view.

BE

Neutral rating – GBP6.4 valuation (14% upside)
Recent underperformance of the shares on renewed credit stress, pressure on diamonds and bulk
commodities prices, makes the valuation undemanding at 0.7x EV/CE. Our new TP (50% trough
50% medium term) implies 14% upside. At a time when sector China momentum continues to
lack traction, we would need evidence on what level diamond profitability will trough and a clearer
balance sheet deleveraging path to turn more positive.

BE

11:30 am
BE

Here's the summary from Mark Wilson of Jefferies, who called this a couple of weeks ago.

BE

And was pretty much the only analyst out there to do so.

BE

AMFW is reducing its dividend by 50% (guiding to 29p/sh in 2015) and projects a 2016 dividend "approximately half that declared in 2014" (43.1p/sh). Operationally, further cost savings have been identified but 2H15 margins are now expected to be lower than 1H15 with "further modest Trading Margin dilution" in 2016. Consensus had been showing an improvement in 2H15 and 2016 margins. The risk to the dividend is a key element of our Underperform view.

11:31 am
BE

The conference call reinforces the points made in our initiation. Yes the company focuses on “reimbursable” contracts rather than “Lump sum” contracts (in contrast to PFC for example) but customers are pushing back hard on seemingly any and all invoices. In a normal “AMEC” world that would mean simple business slowdown but as “AMFW” it has debt as an added burden. It is debt that changes the dynamic for AMFW. History suggests that the company cannot grow without spending on M&A but at the same time the previous “progressive dividend” requires more cash in absolute terms due to a diluted share base (from the deal). Something had to give and today we see the dividend has. Arguably, the outlook for 2016 is also more uncertain post the call. The paragraph below is taken from our initiation on 5 October 2015, 'Growth Card Played - Initiate at Underperform'.

BE

The big deal has happened, further rates of growth questionable. We project below consensus growth assumptions for the combined AMFW. While the acquisition has opened up new regions and product lines, history suggests that organic growth without M&A is low for asset-light, essentially personnel-orientated businesses. Cash for future M&A competes with cash to pay the progressive dividend in addition to servicing (or repaying) the £1bn of net debt. Something has to give we argue, and while there is no pressing debt maturities and the company continues to be well run and respected, the growth expectations built into the consensus' estimates are too optimistic, in our view.

BE

Valuation/Risks. We gave AMFW the benefit of a higher multiple than its peers; at almost 8x average 5yr FY+1 EV/EBITDA multiple the stock trades at a healthy premium to the sector. But on

11:32 am
BE

Or if you want a burnt bull ..............

BE

PM

scorchedfingers

11:32 am
BE

We had been expecting decent results from Amec F-W: expectations which have now been dashed. We are moving our earnings expectations to a more conservative level both for this year and beyond, with large earnings reductions: we now expect trading profit to be down in 2016, even net of the ongoing cost reductions. The information in the release that some "low growth" parts of the business are under review and may be exited is also unwelcome. We now see trading profit (EBITA) of £350m next year, before a cyclical recovery in 2017E. Overall our EPS falls 8%/27%/25% for 15/16/17E.

We retain our BUY: it'll be tough for a little while, though...
Given the large slide in the shares in early trading today we see little point in chasing them down. Whilst much of Amec F-W's business is cyclical, it retains some very strong market positions and has managed to grow new positions - such as in clean energy - which will provide earnings growth in the future. The company's net debt position is substantial, and will grow further in 1H16 on the normal season working capital outflow, but we believe the group will stay comfortably within the 3.25x net debt : EBITDA covenant that is relevant.

Our new price target is 750p (down 29% from 1050p, in-line with our earnings cut), which reflects our continued belief that the stock will trade at a low double-digit earnings multiple and a modest free cash flow yield.

BE

Weird how rarely analysts see dividend cuts coming.

PM

The Company has commissioned Honour Capital, a specialist forestry advisory and management Company, to undertake a valuation review of the new blocks. Honour Capital prepared a valuation report in June 2014 which attributed a NPV to the timber business of US$161 million at a 12% discount based on a 10 year cash flow model. The 2014 valuation was based on 11 concessions with a total land area of 279,965 hectares.

The Company is, subject to local Government approval, completing the acquisition of 50 year leases for two new timber concessions totaling 35,000 hectares in Mozambique to bring the total forestry area to 314,965 hectares. The new blocks are situated adjacent to our main operational centre and, together with the existing holdings, provide a critical mass in terms of approved annual permitted cut.

11:42 am
BE

Here's Deutsche with the summary.

BE

3Q15 results were solid with revenues in-line and Core EPS 2% ahead of consensus despite modestly greater Fx headwinds than assumed. Guidance has been raised but suggests only minor forecast changes after Fx. In terms of sales, Nexium continues to beat expectations, offsetting weak Flumist sales impacted by manufacturing supply disruptions. Performance of the growth platforms was mixed, but overall not meaningfully different from expectations with performance of China particularly comforting (+11% yoy CER). With no meaningful pipeline updates and overall performance encouraging, we expect little to change consensus views. We remain Buyers of AZN's shares given our confidence in a return to above peer-group growth post 2017.

BE

3Q revenues were impacted by an 8% Fx headwind vs our assumed 7%. Within this Nexium ($641m vs $544m) was better and Flumist was below expectations ($76m vs $140m). Performance of the growth platforms was mixed, but overall not meaningfully different from expectations with Brilinta ahead of expectations helped by stocking (+48% CER; 6% above consensus) and Symbicort slightly weak (-4% CER; 3% below consensus). Encouragingly, growth in Japan, EMs and China were strong up 6%, 10% and 11% at CER. Combined externalisation revenues and other operating income of $569m was ahead of consensus of $497m.

11:43 am
BE

Core EPS beat consensus expectations helped by higher “other operating income” and lower finance charges. Management statements continue to underline plans to lower costs. Although these were little different from consensus in the quarter, S,G&A costs were down 11% yoy (3% CER), enabling increased investment in R&D (+18% CER). As a result of overall solid performance, FY15 guidance for both revenue and Core EPS has been raised and looks for flat revenues at CER (vs low single digit decline) and mid-to-high single digit Core EPS growth (vs low single digit). After Fx Core EPS is expected to be broadly in-line with 2014 of $4.28 vs consensus of $4.23 (implying a small 2% upgrade).

BE

And Caz, brief and to the point.

BE

Bottom-line: Overall we don’t expect significant changes to forecasts on the back of these results and the guidance update, and we also don’t see any change in pipeline sentiment. That said, with shares having recently been fairly weak, we could see slight outperformance today.

11:44 am

BE

AstraZeneca (UW/; PT £44/share), 17x 2016 PE, 6% discount. AZN reported sales of $5,950m versus our estimate of $5,980m and company-compiled consensus estimate of $5,924m (1% below BCe and in line with consensus). In terms of earnings, Core EPS came in at $1.03, a 2% beat versus consensus. Core EBIT of $1728m versus our $1,720m and consensus $1,702m is in line with our estimates and 2% beat v consensus. Core EBIT beat was driven primarily by better gross margin in the quarter than expected. Operating margin of 29.1% was above our estimated 28.8% and consensus 28.7%. Top-line guidance upgraded from low single decline to flat (CER) and Core EPS upgraded to mid high single digit increase (CER) due to an improved outlook for Nexium in the US and a strong EM performance, although strong FX headwinds suggest consensus estimates are unlikely to change materially. We expect the focus to shift to the pipeline with the FDA approval decision for lesinurad for the treatment of gout and phase 2 lung cancer data for durvalumab (ATLANTIC trial) potentially supporting an early FDA filing, both expected before year-end.

BE

BE

SuperGroup has delivered a strong H1 trading performance, with group sales up 22.4%
over the period to £254.9m, ahead of our range estimate of £248m - £252m (+18%
to +21%). This was driven by the Retail division, where total sales rose by 30.9% to
£172.2m. The LFL component came in at +17.2% (CGe: +12% - +15%), breaking down
as +19.3% in Q1 and +15.5% for Q2. E-commerce performance was highlighted as a
driver, but was not quantified. We assume the strong momentum of H2's e-commerce
growth has continued throughout H1, before anniversarying in Q3.
The non-LFL contribution of 13.7% was driven by a 21% year-on-year increase in owned
retail space. This included the US stores acquired earlier this year when the US licence
was purchased. Some 14 stores opened in H1, of which 11 were outside the UK and
Republic of Ireland, adding some 63K sq.ft. from the year end, and therefore on track for
the FY guidance of 120K to 130K sq.ft.
Wholesale saw an 8% increase in sterling growth, despite the adverse impact of a
weakening euro. This also includes some contribution, which we estimate at around 2%,
from the North American business.
The H1 gross margin performance will be above the group's full year guidance (range flat
to +30bps). This is principally mix driven, due to the higher growth of higher margin retail,
although these gains have been partially offset by adverse currency movements.
Net cash stood at £80m at the period end, compared with £67m last year.
The company has also appointed Nick Tatum (from Tesco) as Global Retail Director, with
responsibility for retail operations and logistics.

BE

The better than forecast H1 sales growth has led us to increase our FY16 PBT forecast by
£2m (3%) to £71m. This is notwithstanding the much tougher sales comparative in H2,
including the key Christmas period, a likely management bonus (not paid last year) and
a slightly slower trajectory on the US recovery plan. These increases roll through into our
outer year forecasts as well.
We now forecast H1 PBT of £19.0m, up 52% on last year's £12.5m, compared with the
£17.5m - £18.5m range indicated in our note earlier this week - "Everywhere you turn is
opportunity".
